Award.AwardTitle: Development of spirally coiling, force-sensing soft-robot for safe and accurate cochlear electrode implantation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cochlear implant (CI) is fast becoming the main rehabilitation aid for those who suffer from hair cell-related hearing impairments. The nation's current demography suggests that the CI adoption will increase at an accelerated pace for the foreseeable future, calling for more innovations in the CI technology. Of particular urgency is the need for safe and accurate schemes for CI electrode array insertion which is very challenging due to its stringent requirements on insertion depth, electrode-to-wall proximity, and tissue safety. The 3D-spiraling human cochlear anatomy further complicates the task. Many shape-controllable electrodes have been devised to meet the requirements but they still suffer from issues related to limited shape control, slow operation, and potential hazards of electrical actuation. This project focuses on achieving safe and accurate CI electrode insertion through joint utilization of pneumatic soft-robotic micro-tentacles and optical force sensors monolithically integrated with them. Both of them are made of soft elastomers, which greatly facilitates non-intrusive, safe insertion of the CI electrode. The high-level maneuverability of the bio-inspired micro-tentacle will also widen the scope of achievable motion and improve accuracy of the insertion process. Above all, the fusion of agile shape control and integrated sensing will eventually lead to "adaptive insertion" which has been incessantly pursued in CI. All of these will be achieved via the collaboration of two researchers with very different specialty areas, electrical engineering and structural engineering, which will contribute to the convergence in science and technology. This project also aims to strengthen cross-disciplinary training in academia through co-advising of graduate and undergraduate students in seemingly unrelated, yet highly synergistic topics such as optics, MEMS, structural engineering, and computational mechanics. It includes outreach plans to the underrepresented in based on K12 science and technology demonstrations and extra-curricular activities.

This project's ultimate goal of safe and accurate insertion of CI electrode arrays through soft-robotic, sensor-integrated micro-tentacle. Accordingly, the following objectives have been lined up: (1) Development of soft-robotic tentacle capable of performing 3-dimensionally spiraling motion. This task will be carried out as a parallel effort encompassing the microfabrication and testing work by the PI and the computational design, optimization, and analysis by the co-PI. (2) Development of elastomer-based optical force sensors. The key issues of the task include the accomplishment of totally non-intrusive sensing for tissue safety and monolithic, clinically safe integration with the soft-robotic main body. (3) Development of the schemes to fix the shape of the soft-robot upon completion of the insertion process. The key issue is again achieving the goal in a clinically safe fashion. The impact of this unique collaboration will go beyond CI eventually. The importance of micro-robots and soft-robots in rehabilitation and assistive technologies has been in continuous increase in recent years. This project will expedite their fusion and add momentum to the fledgling field of "microscale soft-robotics." The plan to monolithically integrate the shape-control and force-sensing function blocks with the soft-actuator will also contribute to the field of human-friendly robotics which is attracting intense research interests from the robotics community. The resulting additive fabrication and shape-control techniques will enrich the arsenal of additive manufacturing and microscale medical robotics, respectively.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cochlear implants are rapidly emerging as a major rehabilitation aid for those who suffer from hair cell loss-related hearing impairments. Cochlear electrode array implantation is a challenging procedure with stringent requirements on the insertion depth, electrode-to-wall proximity, and tissue safety and the 3D spiraling anatomy of the human cochlea renders the task even more difficult. Given the nation?s aging demography, it is urgent to establish safe and accurate installation schemes for cochlear implants.

This NSF CBET project was created to develop a new soft robotic microscale tentacle actuator for accurate and safe installation of cochlear implants. The use of actuators made of materials softer than human tissue would certainly reduce the risk of possible tissue damage. The key challenge was the integration of the existing technological components and their optimized utilization.

With that in mind, this project started out with a special emphasis on adopting inter- and cross-disciplinary approaches to overcome the challenges. Accordingly, two researchers from two very different specialty areas, microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) and computational data science, joined their forces to carry out optimal design and facile realization of the soft robotic actuator. The project also aimed to develop various supporting technologies for the soft robotic actuator, such as sensors and surface modification techniques, and computational platforms for modeling and optimization. Throughout the project period, the PIs have made progresses in all fronts.

Regarding the realization and optimization of the soft robotic actuator, the PIs have demonstrated a new scheme to design and analyze the deformation of microscale tentacle actuators. Previously, such tasks were done by highly computation-intensive methods such as finite element analysis. The PIs reduced the work into simple matrix calculations by applying ?Line Segment? model. Figure 1 illustrates the concept and result schematically.

Structures and functionalities that can support the operation of future soft robotic microscale tentacle actuators have also been developed. Figure 2 shows the optical contact sensor based on an elastomeric micropillar. They can be attached to the bodies of the microscale tentacle and provide a safe way of sensing its contact with biological tissues. Figure 3 illustrates a new technique to texture the surface of polymer using light-controlled capillary effect. When applied to the surface of soft robotic actuators, the nanotextures can help regulating the mass flow around the actuators.

The PIs also found the optimal structural parameters of the micro-tentacle that can satisfy the design objective of modiolus-hugging multiple-turn shape. To overcome a variety of challenges including multiple turns, changing curvatures, soft materials, and microscopic length scales, we adopted a comprehensive computational, numerical and data-/machine learning-driven approach. First, we departed from the well-established formulations of actuated tentacle-like structures and developed in-house numerical dynamic modeling computer program for computational investigation of dynamic tentacle behaviors. Figure 4 presents example plots of the dynamic behavior of the soft-micro tentacle structure derived by the computational dynamic model.

Despite the valuable understanding of the dynamic behavior gleaned from the computational method, the actual design of desired shape of the micro-soft robotics is a daunting task since many factors are complicatedly interwoven. To tackle this challenge, we developed a modified evolutionary algorithm to achieve the optimal structural parameters. The evolutionary algorithm-driven optimal design of the 3D curling micro-tentacle are shown in Fig. 5.

During the project period, the team found there is a strong need for hidden physics rule identifier behind the complex physics behavior. Therefore, this project sought to develop a glass-box (as opposed to the black-box machine learning) physics rule learner which can help us to explore new frontiers where no known governing rules or equations are available. As a successful proof of concept, the team developed a novel glass-box physics rule learner (GPRL) and validated with nano-scale electrification phenomena which has no known governing equations. Fig. 6 summarizes the promising impact of the GPRL to unravel hidden physics rule over complex 3D point cloud and nano-scale specimen.

All these accomplishments are highly transformative for their inherently cross-disciplinary nature. The PIs have striven to harmonize microscale fabrication, computational optimization, machine-learning, and nanoscale science that will be useful to researchers in a variety of academic fields. The outcomes of this project also provide broader impacts on society, first by offering a potential solution for further promotion of implantable devices and, second, by stimulating interests on data science and related studies. The efforts produced high impact publications in widely subscribed academic journals. Overall, the benefits of these outcomes will reach beyond the field of soft robotics and draw attention from the general public.


Last Modified: 12/15/2020
Modified by: Jaeyoun Kim

Images (1 of )
  • Comparison of the experiment, analytical, and segment-based modeling results for a model micro-tentacle at different values of pressure. They agree well with each other.
    Iowa State University
    Public Domain
    Jaeyoun Kim
    Figure 1
  • (a) Hard PDMS nanocavity fabrication by replica molding. (b) Spatial patterning of the control-light. (c) Preparation of a photopolymer thin film and its UV pre-curing. (d) Attaching the h-PDMS mold to the NOA73 thin film to induce the capillary action. (e) Nanopixel formation via capillary filling.
    Jaeyoun Kim
    Public Domain
    Jaeyoun Kim
    Figure 3
  • Comparison between un-damped and damped free oscillations of the tentacle computationally modeled with three lumped section heads. (a) shows free oscillation without damping effect while (b) show damped free oscillation. (c) shows a numerical modeling of the 3-tentacle soft robotic arm system.
    Iowa State University
    Public Domain
    Jaeyoun Kim
    Figure 4
  • (a) Machine learning-driven optimal design of the three-dimensional cochlear structure. Evolutionary algorithm suggests complex design of 3D curling with local humps for curvature change to the desired 3D shapes. (b) A side-view of a real human cochlea [adopted from Pietch et al. 2017].
    Iowa State University
    Public Domain
    Jaeyoun Kim
    Figure 5
  • Feasibility tests of the novel glass-box physics rule learner (GPRL) with different nano-scale tribocharging experiments: (a,c) Raw experimental data (b,d) predicted electric potentials using the best-so-far physics rule identified by the GPRL. No training data are used.
    Iowa State University
    Public Domain
    Jaeyoun Kim
    Figure 6
  • A soft optical contact sensor: (a) Basic configuration of the contact sensor (Scale bar: 100 μm) (b) The PDMS micropillar is in its 'Non-Contact (NC)' (left) or 'Contact (C)' (right) states. (Scale bars: 250 μm) (c) Changes in reflection level as a function of time.
    Iowa State University
    Public Domain
    Jaeyoun Kim
    Figure 2

The outcomes of this project also provide broader impacts on society, first by offering a potential solution for further promotion of implantable devices and, second, by stimulating interests on data science and related studies. The efforts produced high impact publications in widely subscribed academic journals. Overall, the benefits of these outcomes will reach beyond the field of soft robotics and draw attention from the general public. Last Modified: 12/15/2020 Submitted by: Jaeyoun Kim
